abstract.text: A property wrapper type that you use to create a UIKit app delegate.

inlineContent.text: To handle app delegate callbacks in an app that uses the
SwiftUI life cycle, define a type that conforms to the
protocol, and implement the delegate methods that you need. For example,
you can implement the
method to handle remote notification registration:
Then use the
property wrapper inside your
declaration to tell SwiftUI about the delegate type:
SwiftUI instantiates the delegate and calls the delegateâ€™s
methods in response to life cycle events. Define the delegate adaptor
only in your
declaration, and only once for a given app. If
you declare it more than once, SwiftUI generates a runtime error.
If your app delegate conforms to the
protocol, as in the example above, then SwiftUI puts the delegate it
creates into the
. You can access the delegate from
any scene or view in your app using the
property
wrapper:
This enables you to use the dollar sign (
) prefix to get a binding to
published properties that you declare in the delegate. For more information,
see
Manage an appâ€™s life cycle events without using an app
delegate whenever possible. For example, prefer to handle changes
in
instead of relying on delegate callbacks, like
Some iOS apps define a
to handle scene-based events, like app shortcuts:
You can provide this kind of delegate to a SwiftUI app by returning the
scene delegateâ€™s type from the
method inside your app delegate:
When you configure the
instance, you only need to indicate the delegate class, and not a scene
class or storyboard. SwiftUI creates and manages the delegate instance,
and sends it any relevant delegate callbacks.
As with the app delegate, if you make your scene delegate an observable
object, SwiftUI automatically puts it in the
, from where
you can access it with the
property wrapper, and
create bindings to its published properties.

abstract.text: Declare the user interface and behavior for your app on every platform.
A type that represents the structure and behavior of an app.
An interface for a stored variable that updates an external property of a
view.
A property wrapper that reads a value from a viewâ€™s environment.
A property wrapper type for an observable object that a parent or ancestor
view supplies.
Use a scene-based life cycle in SwiftUI while keeping your existing codebase.

doc://com.apple.SwiftUI/documentation/Sw.title: Migrating to the SwiftUI life cycle

abstract.text: An indication of a sceneâ€™s operational state.
A property wrapper type that you use to create a UIKit app delegate.
Creates a UIKit app delegate adaptor using an observable delegate.
A projection of the observed object that provides bindings to its
properties.
The underlying app delegate.
The user interface to show while an app launches.
The user interfaces to show while an app launches in response to different URL schemes.
A type of object with a publisher that emits before the object has changed.
A set of methods to manage shared behaviors for your app.
Retrieves the configuration data for UIKit to use when creating a new scene.
Tells the delegate that the launch process is almost done and the app is almost ready to run.
Tells the delegate that the app successfully registered with Apple Push Notification service (APNs).
Information about the objects and storyboard for UKit to use when creating a particular scene.
Additional methods that you use to manage app-specific tasks occurring in a scene.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A set of methods to manage shared behaviors for your app.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
